citation.abstract: Obesity is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease. C1q/TNF-related protein (CTRP) 9 is an adipokine that is downregulated by obesity. We investigated the role of CTRP9 in cardiac injury with loss-of-function genetic manipulations, and defined the receptor-mediated signaling pathway downstream of this adipokine. CTRP9-knockout (CTRP9-KO) mice at the age of 12 weeks were indistinguishable from wild-type (WT) mice under basal conditions. CTRP9-KO mice had exacerbated contractile left ventricle dysfunction following intraperitoneal injection of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) compared with WT mice. Administration of LPS to CTRP9-KO mice also resulted in increased expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines and oxidative stress markers in the heart compared with WT mice. Likewise, CTRP9-KO mice showed increased myocardial infarct size and elevated expression of inflammatory mediators in ischemic heart following ischemia-reperfusion compared with WT mice. Treatment of cardiac myocytes with CTRP9 protein led to suppression of LPS-induced expression of pro-inflammatory genes, which was reversed by blockade of AMPK or ablation of adiponectin-receptor type1 (AdipoR1). Systemic delivery of CTRP9 attenuated LPS-induced cardiac dysfunction in WT mice, but not in muscle-specific transgenic mice expressing dominant-negative mutant form of AMPK or AdipoR1-knockout mice. CTRP9 protects against acute cardiac damage in response to pathological stimuli by suppressing inflammatory reactions through AdipoR1/AMPK-dependent mechanisms.
citation.title: C1q/TNF-related protein 9 protects against acute myocardial injury through an AdipoR1-AMPK dependent mechanism.
